title: Abstract for Unit 1 Lesson 7: Setting the Stage
body: Unit 1 Lesson 7, 'Setting the Stage,' focuses on introducing students to Participatory Sensing campaigns, specifically the 'Food Habits Campaign.' The primary objective is for students to collect and record data about their eating habits and those of their classmates. This lesson covers the practical aspects of data collection using mobile devices and the IDS ThinkData Ed app, including app download, login procedures, and survey completion. It also emphasizes important concepts such as data privacy, photo ethics, and the role of students as reliable data collectors. Key vocabulary introduced includes Participatory Sensing, campaign, surveys, images, GPS, ethics, and photo ethics. Students will learn to use the app to collect data on snacks, understand the importance of focusing on snacks rather than full meals, and engage in a 9-day data collection period. The lesson also touches upon setting data collection reminders and monitoring progress.

title: Unit 1 Lesson 7: Objective and Materials
body: The objective of Unit 1 Lesson 7 is for students to begin collecting and recording data to understand their own eating habits and those of their classmates. They will learn about data collection through a Participatory Sensing campaign and discuss privacy issues and photo ethics. Materials required for this lesson include students' mobile devices (iOS or Android) compatible with the App Store or Google Play Store, login information (username and password) for each student, and the 'Food Habits Campaign' guidelines. Optional video resources are available to demonstrate survey taking via browser or app. Access to the IDS ThinkData Ed app is crucial for the data collection process.

title: Vocabulary: Participatory Sensing
body: Participatory Sensing is an approach to data collection and interpretation where individuals, either alone or in groups, utilize their personal mobile devices and web services. This method allows them to explore various aspects of their world, ranging from health to culture, by actively gathering data. In the context of Unit 1 Lesson 7, students act as human sensors within a Participatory Sensing campaign, collecting data about their own eating habits.

title: Vocabulary: Campaign
body: In the context of data collection, a 'campaign' refers to a structured effort to gather and collect specific data. For Unit 1 Lesson 7, the 'Food Habits Campaign' is a defined period and set of activities during which students will collect data related to their snacking habits. This campaign serves as the framework for their participatory sensing activities.

title: Vocabulary: Surveys
body: Surveys are a research method employed for collecting data, enabling the acquisition of information and insights into various topics of interest. In Unit 1 Lesson 7, students will use surveys within the IDS ThinkData Ed app to record data about their food habits. These surveys are designed to gather specific details about the snacks they consume.

title: Vocabulary: Images
body: An 'image' is a representation of the external form of a person, thing, or a picture. Within the context of Unit 1 Lesson 7's 'Food Habits Campaign,' students may be asked to take pictures of their snacks or their nutritional facts labels as part of the data collection process. Strict guidelines on photo ethics apply to ensure privacy.

title: Vocabulary: GPS
body: GPS stands for Global Positioning System. It is a radio navigation system that enables land, sea, and airborne users to determine their exact location. While the IDS ThinkData Ed app may utilize GPS for data collection in other contexts, for the 'Food Habits Campaign' in Unit 1 Lesson 7, student privacy is protected. Any location data shared is generalized and does not display a specific address on the shared IDS map.

title: Vocabulary: Ethics
body: Ethics refers to a code of behavior, specifically concerning what is considered right and wrong. In Unit 1 Lesson 7, understanding ethics is fundamental, particularly in relation to data collection and sharing. Students are taught to consider the ethical implications of their actions, especially when capturing and sharing images.

title: Vocabulary: Photo Ethics
body: Photo ethics are the principles that guide how we take and share photographs. In Unit 1 Lesson 7, students are instructed on specific photo ethics for the 'Food Habits Campaign.' They are forbidden from taking pictures of any person's identifying features, such as faces or hands. Only pictures of snacks and/or their nutritional facts labels are permitted to protect privacy.

title: Essential Concepts: Data Collection in Participatory Sensing
body: In Participatory Sensing, humans act as 'robot sensors,' collecting data when specific 'trigger' events occur. The ability to learn about life patterns through this data hinges on being reliable data collectors. Unit 1 Lesson 7 emphasizes this by having students actively collect data on their eating habits, highlighting their crucial role in the data gathering process.

title: Pre-Campaign Setup and Guidelines
body: Before students commence data collection for the 'Food Habits Campaign' in Unit 1 Lesson 7, it is crucial to ensure that campaign settings are configured according to preference. Teachers can learn about these campaign settings by watching a specific video tutorial. Familiarizing oneself with the 'Food Habits Campaign' guidelines, particularly the 'big questions' under '1. The Issues,' is also recommended to guide students effectively.

title: Distributing Login Information for Data Collection
body: For Unit 1 Lesson 7, login information, including usernames and passwords for the IDS ThinkData Ed app, must be generated and ready for distribution prior to the lesson. This information should be distributed to student team leaders, who will then share it with their team members when preparing to download the app. Safeguards should be in place to ensure that only the legitimate owner can access their login credentials. Students must keep this information confidential throughout the course.

title: Student Reflection on Eating Habits
body: As part of Unit 1 Lesson 7, students are prompted to reflect on the Nutritional Facts labels they collected in the previous lesson. They are asked to consider and record answers in their journals to two key questions: 'What questions would you want answered about eating habits?' and 'What can you do to find out about your own eating habits?' This encourages them to think critically about data and self-observation.

title: Pondering 'What are we really eating?'
body: Unit 1 Lesson 7 encourages students to revisit their reactions and comments from a video (presumably related to food, like Jamie Oliver's). They are then asked to ponder the significant question: 'What are we really eating?' This prompts deeper thinking about the nature of their food consumption beyond just identifying snacks.

title: Engaging in the 'Food Habits Campaign'
body: Over the next 9 days, students in Unit 1 Lesson 7 will participate in a 'Participatory Sensing campaign' focused on 'Food Habits.' During this campaign, they will act as human sensors to gather data about themselves. The collected data will be analyzed to understand their own and their classmates' snacking habits. This hands-on experience introduces them to real-world data collection.

title: Focusing Data Collection on Snacks
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 7's 'Food Habits Campaign,' students are specifically instructed to collect data only for snacks they eat. This means excluding full meals such as breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Examples of snacks include fruit, chips, cookies, nuts, and sodas. The rationale is to focus the data collection on in-between meal consumption patterns.

title: Rationale for Focusing on Snacks
body: The lesson in Unit 1 Lesson 7 encourages students to brainstorm why it makes sense to study snacks specifically, rather than all food consumption. They are asked to consider what types of questions about eating habits could be answered effectively using snack-only data that might be difficult or impossible to answer if data from full meals were included. This exercise highlights the importance of defining data collection scope.

title: Introduction to the IDS ThinkData Ed App for Data Collection
body: Unit 1 Lesson 7 introduces students to the 'Participatory Sensing' data collection method using a mobile application called the 'IDS ThinkData Ed app.' This application is capable of gathering data through various means, including surveys, images, and GPS tracking. The lesson clarifies that while GPS may be used, student location privacy is maintained through generalized location tags, not specific addresses.

title: Clarifying Data Purpose: Self-Learning vs. External Research
body: It is crucial for students in Unit 1 Lesson 7 to understand that the data they collect during the 'Food Habits Campaign' is primarily for their own learning and analysis of their classmates' habits. They are informed that they are NOT providing data for external research teams (e.g., from UCLA). This clarification addresses potential misconceptions about the purpose of using the Participatory Sensing app.

title: Accessing the IDS ThinkData Ed App and Browser Version
body: Students in Unit 1 Lesson 7 have multiple options for participating in the 'Food Habits Campaign.' They can download the native Android app '[IDS ThinkData Ed](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.thinkdataed.app.survey)' from the Google Play Store, the iOS app '[IDS ThinkData Ed](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/ids-thinkdata-ed/id6746621731)' from the iOS App Store, or use a browser-based version available at [https://portal.thinkdataed.org](https://portal.thinkdataed.org). The browser version requires clicking the 'Survey Taking' icon.

title: Logging In and Accessing Campaigns
body: After downloading the IDS ThinkData Ed app or accessing the web portal for Unit 1 Lesson 7, students need to log in using their distributed username and passwords. Once logged in, they will see available 'campaigns.' They should select the 'Food Habits Campaign' by tapping on its name. If no campaigns are visible, a 'refresh' option is available on the top right side of the screen.

title: Completing the First Survey and Understanding Photo Ethics
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 7, after logging into the app or browser version, students are instructed to complete their first survey using one of their collected nutrition facts cutouts or pictures. Following this, the concept of 'ethics,' particularly 'photo ethics,' is discussed. Students are strictly forbidden from taking pictures that include identifying features of people (faces, hands, etc.), and are only allowed to photograph their snacks and/or nutrition facts labels.

title: Teacher's Role in Monitoring Photo Ethics
body: For Unit 1 Lesson 7, teachers play a vital role in ensuring adherence to photo ethics during the 'Food Habits Campaign.' They are advised to inspect students' data collection photos throughout the campaign period and before each data collection session. If any photo is deemed inappropriate, the teacher has the authority to delete the data entry immediately to maintain a safe and ethical data collection environment.

title: Utilizing the Reminder Feature in the IDS ThinkData Ed App
body: To aid students in consistent data collection for the 'Food Habits Campaign' in Unit 1 Lesson 7, the IDS ThinkData Ed app offers a reminder feature. Students can set up these reminders directly within the app. This is typically done by accessing the menu (usually via a button on the top left) and selecting the 'Notifications' option, ensuring they don't forget to log their snacks.

title: Establishing Data Collection Norms and Monitoring
body: During Unit 1 Lesson 7, students are asked to estimate the number of snacks they consume daily. Based on this, an approximate target number of surveys to be completed during the 9-day data collection period (days 7-15) is established. The teacher informs students that their data collection progress will be monitored to ensure regular submission of surveys.

title: Reviewing Previous Homework and Sharing Statistical Questions
body: Unit 1 Lesson 7 includes a review of the previous day's homework. Facilitators from each table group conduct a round-robin session where team members share their statistical questions. The Recorder/Reporter then selects and presents the team's statistical questions—one of each type (summary, comparison, association)—to the entire class, facilitating a broader understanding of data inquiry.

title: Class Scribes: Identifying Key Topics
body: In Unit 1 Lesson 7, a designated team of students serves as 'Class Scribes.' Their responsibility is to present a brief talk discussing what they believe were the three most important topics covered during the day's lesson. This activity encourages critical thinking and synthesis of the lesson's core concepts.

title: Homework: Continued Data Collection for 'Food Habits Campaign'
body: The homework assignment for Unit 1 Lesson 7 extends over the next 9 days. Students are required to continue collecting nutritional facts data through the 'Food Habits' Participatory Sensing campaign. This data collection can be performed using their smart devices or via a web browser, reinforcing the practical application of the concepts learned in the lesson.
